name: 1h-carbazole, 2,3,4,9-tetrahydro-
Reason: 1H-carbazole has a melting point that is influenced by its structural components. Starting with the base of benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5 °C, we have a significant structural component to consider. The basic unit for our comparison will be 1,2-diphenylethanol, which has a melting point of 106 degrees Celsius. The structural modifications we need to consider are the presence of two additional phenyl rings. Phenyl groups, when connected to a benzene ring, tend to increase the melting point due to the enhancement of the crystalline structure and the increase in molecular weight. In the case of 1h-carbazole, we have two additional phenyl rings linked in a linear fashion, which would notably augment the melting point. Each additional phenyl group can be estimated to add approximately 100°C to the melting point due to increased pi-pi interactions, rigidity, and molecular weight.
